content:
I am starting to learn categorical logic/algebra and I was wondering how special was Set\mathbf{Set}Set in the statement of completeness of algebraic theories (e.g. 1.1.29 here). The proof seems to say that Set\mathbf{Set}Set isn't more special than usual (i.e. it is the category where we enrich everything and Yoneda lemma is great). So I thought maybe there is a characterization of what types of theories (algebraic, regular, etc...) are complete with respect to Set\mathbf{Set}Set models (I even thought this could be true for any type of theory, but nlab says that it does not work for infinitary theories). I found an earlier discussion here that lead to this comment which sounds great.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

but non-trivial completeness results such as "true in all set-models iff provable in the theory" are recovered as soon as there are 'enough' Set-models for the corresponding functors to be jointly conservative.

Can someone point me to a formal version of this comment?
Yep, look to section D1.5 of Johnstone's Sketches of an Elephant.
Regular theories have enough set-models constructively, coherent theories have enough set-models non-constructively, and general geometric theories can fail to have enough set-models.
Thank you! This chapter had many many answers to my questions.
